I just completed the 100% Steam achievements with a play time of about 60 hours and here is my review. 

Shadow of Mordor was released in 2014, a tricky time for game developers as it was a transition between Playstation 3 to 4 and Xbox 360 to One. I had 2 copies 1 for PS3 and another for PC to test it and just ran through the Campaign and completed it in about 15 hours. I never liked the combat back then, found the nemesis system interesting but the lore was a big disappointment for many LOTR Fans. I remember this game was criticised for being a copycat of Assassin's creed free running at the time of its release including the air assassinations but it actually plays out differently. Its basically Arkham series style rhythm-based combat with excellent crowd control and fluidity. 

Fast forward to 2025 considering the quality of games these days, this game feels like a gem to play. I needed some marathon single player game for Halloween and Shadow of Mordor became my go to choice. Despite a boring routine revenge main story and a lack of memorable characters beyond Talion and Celebrimbor, the developers made an excellent compensation with the much loved Nemesis system which gives the Orcs a lot of personality making an individual gamer's experience totally random and unique. 

The Orcs are the real stars of the game and the reason one would love to play the game and with the Nemesis system you can play this forever if you want as there is no ending as an Orc can become a Captain and then a War-Chief for Talion to defeat. 

Overall Middle-earth‚Ñ¢: Shadow of Mordor‚Ñ¢ has very good Nostalgia factor. It does have outdated graphics for new gamers but it has an enjoyable combat system with Nemesis. The campaign and boss battles are pretty bad but the funny Orcs and their non stop banter and complaints of just about everything will keep anyone engaged. If you got bored simply go any stronghold and listen to the Orcs talk to themselves and you will be entertained.

Cheers! Have Fun!

Shadow of Mordor is an action-adventure game set between The Hobbit and The Lord of the Rings, but it is not a direct retelling of Tolkien‚Äôs stories. Instead, it uses Middle-earth as a backdrop for an original tale. The result is a game that captures the atmosphere and themes of Tolkien‚Äôs world, but also takes major creative liberties that some fans appreciate and others question.

üéÆ Atmosphere & Lore Faithfulness
‚úî The World Feels Like Middle-earth

The game effectively portrays Mordor as a grim, dangerous, corrupted place, matching Tolkien‚Äôs descriptions.

Orcs (or ‚ÄúUruk-hai‚Äù in the game) have detailed personalities, rivalries, and hierarchies ‚Äî something Tolkien hinted at, but never explored in depth.

The tone of the world is appropriately bleak but mythic, fitting the era before Sauron fully rises.

‚úî Use of Tolkien Locations & Factions

N√∫men√≥rean ruins, slave pits, forges, and fortresses reflect a history consistent with the Second and Third Age stories.

Gollum appears, and his presence fits naturally into the timeline ‚Äî his obsession with the Ring and sneaking through Mordor aligns with the lore.

‚öîÔ∏è Characters & Canon Deviations

This is where Shadow of Mordor takes the biggest liberties.

‚ùó Talion (the protagonist)

Talion is an original character, not found in Tolkien‚Äôs works.

His ‚Äúrevenant ranger‚Äù concept ‚Äî a man sharing a body with a wraith ‚Äî is cool but not grounded in Tolkien‚Äôs established magic.

Tolkien‚Äôs world rarely allows humans to return from death in this way.

‚ùó Celebrimbor‚Äôs portrayal

This is the most controversial lore decision.

In Tolkien‚Äôs legendarium, Celebrimbor is a tragic figure who forged the Rings under Sauron‚Äôs deception.

In the game, Celebrimbor is a vengeful ghost who:

Bonds with Talion,

Forms armies,

Enthralls orcs,

Forges a new Ring (in the sequel).

These actions do not align with Tolkien‚Äôs portrayal of Celebrimbor, who is far more humble, noble, and morally grounded.

üî• Themes: Faithful or Not?
‚úî Faithful Themes

Resistance against a growing evil.

Corruption's influence over mortals.

The tragedy of N√∫menor‚Äôs legacy.

The danger of power and domination.

These ideas are very Tolkien-accurate.

‚ùó Less Faithful Themes

The game focuses heavily on revenge, domination, and hunting orcs for power.

Tolkien‚Äôs works emphasize:

Mercy > vengeance

Hope > despair

Free will > domination

Humility > brute force

The game leans toward a darker, more power-fantasy-oriented interpretation.

‚öñÔ∏è Does the Game ‚ÄúFit‚Äù Into Tolkien‚Äôs Canon?

Not really ‚Äî it fits the style and aesthetic of Middle-earth, but it isn‚Äôt canonically accurate.

Most fans agree on this breakdown:

‚úî Lore-Compatible Elements

Mordor‚Äôs geography and culture

Orc behavior and hierarchy

Gollum‚Äôs involvement

Mood, tone, and world-building

‚ùó Lore-Breaking Elements

Talion returning from death through wraith magic

Celebrimbor as a combat-ghost general

Mind-controlling and dominating Uruks

Forging new Rings

Some events contradict established timelines

Shadow of War is a rare gem in open-world action games, thanks to its unmatched(unfortunately copyrighted) Nemesis System. Every encounter feels personal‚Äîorc captains adapt to your playstyle, remember your failures, and even come back for revenge (or to save your skin from one). The first two maps deliver a gripping story, but the later game devolves into repetition, leaving you wondering, "Why am I doing this again?" Still, the journey is worth it.

Combat and progression shine, especially on higher difficulties, where every victory feels earned. The skill trees add meaningful depth, and managing your orc army is a blast‚Äîthough it‚Äôs frustrating you can‚Äôt bring your elite squad with you to new regions easily.

The world is immersive at first but grows repetitive, and 100% completion feels like a bit of a chore. But it is still a must play for Souls-like fans and RPG lovers who want a world that reacts to them. Just be ready to die, run, lose fights, adapt, and embrace the chaos.

Final tip: Start on the highest difficulty and work your way down if you are not making slow progress. The game rewards persistence, and the Nemesis System makes every death part of the story.

I recommend the game with many caveats, and somewhat begrudgingly.

Positives:
1. The game is beautiful for a game of its time if your PC can run it in maxed out settings.
2. The combat is very fun for the most part. It is visceral and eye catching, and the counter system it takes from the Arkham series is very well implemented.
3. Captains are a lot of fun to experience. They have different designs, have their own intro lines, and when you can start dominating the game actually becomes a lot more fun in my opinion.

Negatives:
1. The cast feel like narrative vehicles rather than people you can relate to or care about. They seem interesting at first, but they ultimately have no utility, you never see or experience them outside of scripted story sequences, and the emotional stakes they are meant to enforce fall flat. 
2. The captains, while really cool in many ways, also become a source of frustration as some are immune to most attacks. Toward the end of the game the generals can have small armies of captains that overwhelm you pretty easily, especially when orc peons are literally endlessly populating and jumping you from behind. Trying to chase them down and finish them becomes a chore and source of annoyance as every other enemy gets in your way making it difficult to catch them. When you can start dominating captains, it is often very difficult as you are still getting constantly attacks which interrupts the attempt. Overall it is fun killing captains, but they too are endless, which wears thin after a while as it feels like a Hydra-like scenario where one head cut from the body just grows back, making you feel like you're not really making progress.
3. Stealth sequences can be really frustrating later as you have to repeat the same mission from the beginning for even one mistake, and some of the missions become quite long and hard to avoid "detection" successfully. Eventually I just stopped trying to unlock my knife fully.
4. The story overall falls pretty flat, though the dynamic between the two protagonists is mildly entertaining.
5. Bosses seem epic, then you discover one is just a quick time event and the other is a lame stealth drain even, taking away the excitement and leading to a very weak climactic final "battle".
6. The lame game abilities are much more fun, like dominating Caragor and Draug, but they are temporary rather than permanent mounts, which feels pretty lame ultimately as they die pretty easy and just become animal like transport vehicles losing their appeal.
7. The world is open world style like Assassins creed, but there is literally nothing interesting going on it. You just travel from one mission marker to another, fighting enemies and captains along the way, and occasionally picking up collectibles, which are voice narrative (which seems cool but mostly isn't since they are random lore sequences and not really about the characters most of the time).
8. Lastly, you wear the same outfit and use the same weapons the entire game. You can upgrade them, and they are further augmented with artifacts and by completing missions to strengthen them and unlock your move sets, but it felt a bit lame that nothing really visibly changed and that the environment was about unlocking stat bonuses and abilities, though your combat moves are largely the same the entire game, making exploration feel pretty pointless to me. 

Ultimately, there are many cool ideas, but the game itself feels a bit more like a shell of a game built around a single gimmick more than anything. I hear the second game is much better, so I'm hopeful I will enjoy it more, and that they will capitalize on the interesting ideas of the original without it falling flat mid game. I say play it so you have an understanding of the game mechanics, so you can import your captain for the next game, and so you can experience the relationship between the two protagonists (though honestly a quick video summary would be perfectly sufficient as this is not a deep relationship really).

[h1]Middle-earth: Shadow of Mordor Review[/h1]

[hr]
[h1]Overview[/h1]
Even if you are not deep into Middle-earth lore, Shadow of Mordor is a very fun, very playable action game with a classic charm. Tight combat, a unique enemy system that makes fights personal, and a world that is easy to roam and grind in. I recommend it.

[hr]
[h1]What It Is[/h1]
You play as Talion, a ranger bound to the wraith Celebrimbor after tragedy strikes at the Black Gate. Together you hunt Uruk captains and warlords across Mordor, uncovering who pulled the strings and why, while your wraith powers grow and the Uruks remember every clash.

[hr]
[h1]World and Atmosphere[/h1]
Mordor is bleak but striking. Two large zones packed with forts, camps, and roaming warbands. It is fantasy-heavy and combat-forward, with lots of patrols to ambush and strongholds to crack. For 2014 the visuals hold up well, and the orc variety plus ambient chatter sell the setting.

[hr]
[h1]Combat and Abilities[/h1]
If you like Arkham-style fighting, you will click here fast. Strike to build combo, react to counters, finish, then chain executions and wraith skills. It starts simple and gets better as you unlock more moves, ranged bow shots, stealth tools, and crowd control. You can go full stealth, full brawler, or mix both on the fly.

[hr]
[h1]Nemesis System (The Secret Sauce)[/h1]
Uruks have names, traits, fears, and grudges. Captains who kill you rank up and taunt you later. You learn weaknesses, exploit them, then either execute or dominate to turn enemies into assets. This creates organic mini-stories and keeps encounters fresh in a way few games match.

[hr]
[h1]Story and Characters[/h1]
Paced well and not too long. I liked it overall even without deep Lord of the Rings knowledge. Talion and Celebrimbor carry the plot, cutscenes are well acted, and the orc personalities land thanks to strong voice work and facial animation.

[hr]
[h1]Performance and Polish[/h1]
Runs smoothly on modern PCs and current consoles. Facial animation and sync are still impressive. Occasional open-world repetition shows its age, but nothing critical.

[hr]
[h1]What Works[/h1]
[list]
[*] Addictive Arkham-like combat that expands as you progress
[*] Nemesis system makes every death and victory matter
[*] Lots of captain hunts and strongholds to pick apart your way
[*] Surprising variety in orc traits and banter
[*] Solid voice acting and cutscene presentation
[/list]

[hr]
[h1]What Falls Short[/h1]
[list]
[*] Open-world activities can repeat if you chase everything
[*] World detail is more functional than richly interactive
[*] Some systems reveal their best tricks only after a few hours
[/list]

[hr]
[h1]Verdict[/h1]
Thumbs up. Shadow of Mordor is a fast, satisfying power fantasy with memorable enemy dynamics. Even if Middle-earth lore is not your thing, the gameplay loop and Nemesis system make this an easy recommendation.

I was sceptical about it since i`ve never played a stealth game likes this before. But during sales I got both Middle-Earth games for 7 bucks so I just thought "why not?". Not like there is a lot of money I would waste. Now I can say, best investment ever. If it wasn`t for this game, I would never have gotten into the stealth genre. Though calling it a stealth game propably isn`t correct either, it`s more like a toolbox kind of game. Here is the complete breakdown.

1. Graphics. 
A bit dated considering it`s age but the art style is amazing, it really gives off a middle-earth feeling, dark yet beautiful. You really feel like you are in a Peter Jackson movie. The character designs in general are what you would expect from a Lord of the Rings game but where they really nailed it is the Orc and Uruk design. They all look dsictinct from each other with a lot of love for detail. Considering it`s age, this game looks great and still holds up. 9/10.

2. 
Story. Not too much to write home about. It`s a generic middle-earth story concerning a dark master and rings. It`s loosley based on the Lord of the Rings but barely any characters are canon. It`s best to view this as a parallel universe story. Nothing that gets you too invested but good enough to drive you forward. 7/10.

3. Gameplay.
This is what you are really playing this game for. It`s not like a hack x slash game at all, it`s a toolbox kind of combat system. The game gives you several ways of approaching combat and enemies. Shoot them from afar with your bow, sneak up on an enemy to assasinate him or directly confront him. Stealth is great because it can instantkill all mobs without having to engage them, which is especially great agains shielded enemies. The great thing though is, I`ve found myself using the entire arsenal throughout the game, none of the tools and skills are useless. You could try to handle and entire horde of Orcs and it`s definitely possible but very time consuming. Just shoot an arrow into a fire pit to let it explode. If you fance it, you can even grab enemies and throw them into the fire pit or just throw them off a cliff. As you progress, you unlock new skills that are very nice. Shadow Strike must be my favorite skill. Instantly teleport to an enemy to execute them and if you update it, you can even chain it. It`s a lot of fun to experiment and there is too much to explain it all in detail here. The Nemesis System is of course what people love the most about it. You can continue playing this game endlessly and it never gets boring. 10/10.

Overall score: 9/10. If you are not sure if this kind of game is for you then buy it for 3 bucks during sales. If it`s not for you, you at least didn`t spend much money of it. But for the ones who like these kind of games, it will be your best deal ever.

negative.review:
Extremely mid. The nemesis system is neat, but the rest of the game is incredibly bland. I love open world checklists, but not when the whole world is dreary and dull, with undetailed copy and pasted ruins everywhere, and only orcs to look at. No towns, no anything else. That is genuinely the entire game world, besides a couple caves. Not to mention a story that genuinely feels like fanfiction (I'm sorry, I know that's cliche to say), a protagonist that's a generic muscle cool man, and possibly the most anticlimactic final two bosses in recent memory. I could only recommend if you really wanna fight some orcs, and nothing else, for about 15 hours. 

That said, it's fine. I had some fun in there. But it feels like a proof of concept. I hope the sequel is better and I will be playing it, because I had so much higher hopes!

The gamepad interaction is kinda dull. I have a Steam-compatible gamepad and the maneuvering of Talion (main character) feels laggy. Also, when using the right stick to control the camera view, it is either too slow or too fast independently of how you adjust the settings.

Parts of the game are a lot of fun, usually when you're hunting and branding captains. Unfortuantely the rest of your time is spent of simple, dull, and short story missions. I would venture a guess that most of the game is supposed to be drawn out by all typical kinds of busy work you'd expect in an assassin's creed-esque title. 

The bosses were also a let-down because there's not much to fight; most of the time it seems to resolve into a few set-piece encounters or QTE's. 

All-in-all I would say this LOTR game is decent for the unique mechanic offered, but you can't expect all that much else out of it. Rather short game, with not a lot worth doing.

Extremely mid. The nemesis system is neat, but the rest of the game is incredibly bland. I love open world checklists, but not when the whole world is dreary and dull, with undetailed copy and pasted ruins everywhere, and only orcs to look at. No towns, no anything else. That is genuinely the entire game world, besides a couple caves. Not to mention a story that genuinely feels like fanfiction (I'm sorry, I know that's cliche to say), a protagonist that's a generic muscle cool man, and possibly the most anticlimactic final two bosses in recent memory. I could only recommend if you really wanna fight some orcs, and nothing else, for about 15 hours. 

That said, it's fine. I had some fun in there. But it feels like a proof of concept. I hope the sequel is better and I will be playing it, because I had so much higher hopes!

SPOILERS ALERT. Game is fun for a short-running game. I actually like the fact that it's somewhat of a sandbox, nonstop action game but at the same time it lacks depth in story telling. The gameplay is its biggest strength, it has a very innovative nemesis system, combat is pretty fun and you feel powerful when unlocking each talent (Though it deserves more polishing). Graphics looks mid for its time so it really isn't the greatest looking game.

[spoiler] Unfortunately the ending feels rushed, each 'boss' turned lazily made one after another especially up to the end. There wasn't even a final boss fight, just a sequence of quick time events that you need to watch, which is a bummer because there is so much potential in the combat mechanics that could have made an interesting well designed boss fight.[/spoiler]

EDIT: When I heard that warner bros PATENTED the nemesis system, and has shut down monolith games as a 'strategic decision", I changed this review from positive to negative since I heavily disagree with their company's practice.

The gamepad interaction is kinda dull. I have a Steam-compatible gamepad and the maneuvering of Talion (main character) feels laggy. Also, when using the right stick to control the camera view, it is either too slow or too fast independently of how you adjust the settings.

Parts of the game are a lot of fun, usually when you're hunting and branding captains. Unfortuantely the rest of your time is spent of simple, dull, and short story missions. I would venture a guess that most of the game is supposed to be drawn out by all typical kinds of busy work you'd expect in an assassin's creed-esque title. 

The bosses were also a let-down because there's not much to fight; most of the time it seems to resolve into a few set-piece encounters or QTE's. 

All-in-all I would say this LOTR game is decent for the unique mechanic offered, but you can't expect all that much else out of it. Rather short game, with not a lot worth doing.
